Home Mush The Lounge Roleplay[SG][RP][SA] The Open Story
On june 23, 2014
[8356287]

[STORY GAME]
[ROLE-PLAYING]
[SHARED AUTHORSHIP]

I love the open-ended collaboration of forum adventures and story games. Everyone can be a part of the creative process, and no one can predict how the story will unfold. But many of these stories seem to fizzle out and die at some point, because their authors get busy and move on. So I'd like to try something different. Let's write a story together, but with decentralized editorial power shared amongst all of us. Here is a set of rules that will allow this story to take on a life of its own.

Each participant (including me) will play the role of a single character. We will all share the roles of NPCs and the Narrator. I will be a facilitator, helping to keep the process organized and moving forward. But I'm not in control - the power is shared equally by all players, and anyone can perform the tasks of facilitation if they understand the rules.

Dialogue and actions of player characters are automatically accepted into the story. Players cannot control another player's character. But any player can control the Narrator and NPCs, to guide the story in any direction they wish. However, these contributions must be accepted by the other players. When a contribution is accepted, it will become the decision point for the NEXT contribution.

There are two ways a contribution can be accepted: by vote, or by default. Any 3 players (not including the contributor) can vote to accept a contribution into the story, which will take effect immediately when the 3rd acceptance vote is posted. Down-votes are not allowed. A contribution will be accepted by default if no alternative contribution is posted within 24 hours, regardless how many votes it has. So if you don't like a certain contribution, you can (and should) write an alternative contribution to replace it, within 24 hours. Then we'll vote on which one to accept, by relative majority, one vote per player. The vote will be closed exactly 24 hours after the alternative contribution is posted. Any further contributions posted in competition for the same vote will not reset the vote's deadline. Players may change their vote at any time until the vote is closed. Acceptance votes posted before the alternative will still be counted toward the first contribution, unless those players change their votes. If a vote ends in a tie, we'll roll dice to break the tie: d100, highest wins, re-roll a tie. Any player can make the tie-breaking dice rolls.

All contributions must be fully consistent with all previously accepted contributions. You can write a contribution extending from another contribution that hasn't been accepted yet, but if an alternative to it is accepted instead, then yours will also be overturned. Please begin each contribution with a quote of the contribution you're extending from, so we can identify which ones are alternatives and keep track of any parallel timelines. Within 24 hours of a timeline split, only one timeline will be accepted - the rest of them never happened.

When a player character attempts an important action that might fail, a d100 dice must be rolled to determine whether it was successful. But first we have to determine the character's chance of success for that action, so don't roll the dice yet! Please describe the action you want to attempt, and declare the percentage chance you believe you should have, based on your character's biography. For example, if your character is an expert marksman and you're trying to shoot a rope at 100 meters, you might claim 95% chance of success. But any other player can propose a different percentage chance for that action. Your actual chance of success will be the rounded average of all proposed percentages, including your own. For example, if I dispute your 95% chance, and instead propose 80%, but someone else proposes 90%, then your actual chance of success will be 88%, so you must roll 88 or less to succeed. All proposed percentages must be greater than 0% and less than 100%. This percentage-averaging vote will remain open until the moment you roll the dice. After you declare an action, you must wait at least 12 hours before you can roll for it. But you must roll within 36 hours, otherwise your action will be cancelled. Actions occur within the story at the moment they are first declared, so any subsequent contributions inconsistent with the outcome will be overturned as an alternate timeline that never happened. Regardless of success or failure, what happens next will be a decision point for the next contribution. If you're not sure whether to roll for a certain action, just go ahead and post it as a simple action, and any other player can request you to roll for it if they think you should. NPCs don't roll for any of their actions.

Other than character actions and dialogue, every detail of the story should be written through the voice of the omniscient Narrator, in the past tense. Write in the format of a screenplay, labeling each contribution with the name of the role in ALL-CAPS, like this:

NARRATOR: It was a dark and stormy night...
ROBERT: I have a bad feeling about this! (use a colon for dialogue)
ROBERT picks up the sword. (no colon for action)
ROBERT hacks into the central computer. (75% chance) (dice roll required)

Any post that doesn't have a role label will be assumed to be out-of-character meta discussion. (That's totally okay and we'll probably do a lot of it.) Please keep each contribution for each role in a separate post. You can make 2 contributions at a time, but then you must wait for another player's contribution before you can contribute again. Double- and triple-posting is allowed in this thread.

Only players with a living player character can participate in votes. This rule does not apply at the beginning of the story, it will only take effect after the player characters are introduced. The purpose of this rule is basically community moderation - we can simply kill off any griefers, so they can't derail the story. Player characters will be considered NPCs at the moment of death, so their actions can be undone by any other player within 24 hours by posting an alternative contribution for that character. Then maybe their death never happened, and the story can go in a different direction, with that character controlled by the group. But be careful with this rule, because if you kill another player's character without a good reason, you might be killed as a griefer too. When in doubt, you should respect other players' contributions as fair play.

Player characters will be considered NPCs after the player has been inactive for 3 consecutive days. Players can resume control of their character after they return from being inactive, and they can rewrite the previous 24 hours of their character's actions and dialogue.

A player can choose to become a different character, even an existing NPC. When they do, their previous character will become an NPC, and the player must wait at least 7 days before they can change characters again.

Players can propose to change the rules. We'll decide by vote, with a 7 day deadline.

To make the story easy to follow, I'll post a summary near the top of every odd page number: 3, 5, 7, etc. So you can skip through and just read those summaries to catch up.

We'll begin with some narration to set the scene and maybe introduce some NPCs. Then you should try to guide the narration to a point where you can introduce your own character. Feel free to give any back-story for your character, but remember you can always add more details later, even when you're attempting an action that depends on it. No need for numeric attributes, just give general descriptions, such as "very strong" or "dumb as rocks". Let's just say it's a Fantasy/Sci-fi cross-over universe, to keep it really open-ended. Magic and technology, orcs and aliens, studded leather and laser blasters - anything goes.

I'm not going to re-write anything, so your contributions will become part of the story as-is. But don't worry about perfect English or great writing, just try to be clear about your meaning and have fun!

NARRATOR:

A searing flash and a thunderous blast
erupted the Senate floor.
The rubble and flame, and the bodies they claim,
obstructed the grand entrance door.

The screaming that followed was echoed and hollowed
by shock through the senator's ears.
The peace had been broken without a word spoken,
at last, after so many years.

They cowered and ran, without any plan,
no time to think or debate.
But who was behind it, and why were they blinded
by ever such violent hate?

You don't have to write in poetic style, I just did that for the fun of it. Write however you want!

NARRATOR:

A searing flash and a thunderous blast
erupted the Senate floor.
The rubble and flame, and the bodies they claim,
obstructed the grand entrance door.

The screaming that followed was echoed and hollowed
by shock through the senator's ears.
The peace had been broken without a word spoken,
at last, after so many years.

They cowered and ran, without any plan,
no time to think or debate.
But who was behind it, and why were they blinded
by ever such violent hate?

NARRATOR:

Lieutenant David Stafford jumped as his office window shattered. A tall bookcase struck his back and pinned him to his desk. Groaning from the pain of a broken rib, he shoved the books away and struggled out from beneath the bookcase. Without hesitating, he drew his firearm and ran into the hallway, gasping for air. A thick cloud of dust and smoke billowed from the end of the hall, and his mind reeled with the possibilities of what had just happened.

A woman was lying unconscious on the floor. It was that pretty girl from the records department. He briefly knelt down to check her vitals, and she moaned softly. She didn't seem to be injured, so he proceeded toward the Senate chamber.

As he approached, he could hear the hellish fire raging ahead, and the sounds of chaos and terror just beyond it. He had to crouch down to keep his head below the acrid smoke. The heat was intense, almost unbearable. He realized he couldn't get through the main entrance, so he retreated back into the hallway.

He took the woman's arm around his neck and propped her weight against his back, wincing at the strain on his broken rib. He staggered to the vestibule and put his shoulder to the door outside, but it didn't budge. Taking a step back, he kicked it as hard as he could. It swung out and slammed against the wall, and he dragged the woman down the steps and laid her on the pavement.

He took a deep breath of cool, clean air, and turned back toward the building. Part of the roof had collapsed, and a black plume boiled up into the sky. Survivors in scorched and bloody suits were crawling out the windows.

His radio chirped and a frantic voice started shouting from it.

[8356287]

Oh... and um... can I decide how 'strong' my character is? (e.g. magic use, whether or not i have a super awesome mech suit, etc)

Absolutely! Every detail of your own character is yours to create. Personally, I like to play a balanced character, with some weaknesses in addition to strengths. Seems to make it more interesting... But it's up to you! You can be ridiculously powerful if you like. There's no objective, no winning or losing - we're just writing a story. That's why I didn't include any combat mechanics. The game-like elements of the rules are only there to support the role-playing, not the other way around, like most RPGs. So you can be a hero or a villain or anything in between. I tried to keep the setting neutral enough that people can take it wherever they want. Mech Suit? Awesome, I love it.


Currently, i'm trying to wrap my head around how to introduce my character.

For example, could i say: NARRATOR: Meanwhile... nearby, but not so close as to be seen, hidden in smoke etc, etc

While giving a +1 vote to the previous above because it works for leading into an introduction?
Ii've already figured my character. Just having the problem of adding him in.

The example intro you gave sounds like it would work perfectly. Another option might be the voice on the radio. Who is it? What do they say? Maybe it's the Captain warning the Lieutenant about somebody in a Mech Suit... Or maybe it's the person in the Mech Suit in hot pursuit of the perpetrators. Who knows?

The easiest way to introduce a character might be a scene change. You could break away to another city or another planet if you need to. It might be tricky to weave the other scene back into this one, but that's just part of the fun of writing a story. We'll probably end up with a lot of "Meanwhile..." narration bouncing back and forth between scenes, but that's okay.

We also have at least 2 NPCs at this point, the Lieutenant and the unconscious woman. So if anybody wants to take over one of them as their own character, go for it.


I really think we need to have more competition but I can't think of good.
YES! The last contribution has one vote, maybe two. So it's definitely still an option for anyone to post an alternative to compete with it.

On june 24, 2014
[8356287]

I think I've got it.

No more acceptance votes. Every contribution is instantly accepted, and they have to be consistent with everything before it. So you don't have to quote anything, just post the next one.

BUT - you can declare an AUTHOR BATTLE!

You have to post your battle contribution within 48 hours of the one you're battling to replace. THEN we vote on it, with a 24-hour deadline. To declare battle, make your post in this form:

===AUTHOR BATTLE!===
[Quote of contribution you're battling to replace]

====CONTENDER:====

[Your contribution]

So basically, we should just try to roll with the flow. But if somebody wants to take the story in a different direction, they can jump in and rewrite up to 48 hours of history, subject to vote. So even if we get visited by trolls or something, we can always come back and fix whatever they wrecked.

I bumped it up to 48 hours because people need time to write, and I think battles will be relatively rare. Other than that, it's effectively the same as the acceptance rules, but much simpler. There will be less clutter in the thread, and progress will be much faster.

Make it so!

[8356287]

Let's drop the NARRATOR label. It should be easy enough to recognize the difference between narration and OOC discussion.

===

The sky darkened further as the Med ship loomed into view above the Senate building, slowing to hover just above the lawn.

DAVID: It's been almost a minute and a half - why are they so late?

The hatch opened and the stairs folded out. Medics and firefighters streamed out and rushed toward the building.

Suddenly, David's eyes darted back up to the plume of black smoke - he heard something up there. It seemed almost mechanical, like motors whirring... He strained to peer through the thick cloud, but couldn't see anything.

His radio chirped and a frantic voice started shouting from it.

VOICE ON THE RADIO: "HELLO? IS ANYONE ALIVE? I CAN HELP YOU!"

Briefly startled, David looked down at the woman on the ground, who was beginning to regain consciousness. He placed a finger behind his ear and replied.

DAVID: Copy that. Lieutenant David Stafford here, in front of the Senate building. Numerous injured. First responders are on the scene, but we'll need all the help we can get. If you have any training in emergency response or first aid, please report to the Field Coordinator in the Med ship.

A medic approached and knelt beside the woman, who was struggling to sit up.

David looked warily back up at the plume, which had taken on a strange green color. He cocked his head sideways and began walking toward the other end of the building, to get a better view.

===SUMMARY===

The sky darkened further as the Med ship loomed into view above the Senate building, slowing to hover just above the lawn.

DAVID: It's been almost a minute and a half - why are they so late?

The hatch opened and the stairs folded out. Medics and firefighters streamed out and rushed toward the building.

Suddenly, David's eyes darted back up to the plume of black smoke - he heard something up there. It seemed almost mechanical, like motors whirring... He strained to peer through the thick cloud, but couldn't see anything.

His radio chirped and a frantic voice started shouting from it.

VOICE ON THE RADIO: "HELLO? IS ANYONE ALIVE? I CAN HELP YOU!"

Briefly startled, David looked down at the woman on the ground, who was beginning to regain consciousness. He placed a finger behind his ear and replied.

DAVID: Copy that. Lieutenant David Stafford here, in front of the Senate building. Numerous injured. First responders are on the scene, but we'll need all the help we can get. If you have any training in emergency response or first aid, please report to the Field Coordinator in the Med ship.

A medic approached and knelt beside the woman, who was struggling to sit up.

David looked warily back up at the plume, which had taken on a strange green color. He cocked his head sideways and began walking toward the other end of the building, to get a better view.

===

COMPREHENSIVE SUMMARY
_________________________________________________

PAGE 1:
_________________________________________________

Versatio
A searing flash and a thunderous blast
erupted the Senate floor.
The rubble and flame, and the bodies they claim,
obstructed the grand entrance door.

The screaming that followed was echoed and hollowed
by shock through the senator's ears.
The peace had been broken without a word spoken,
at last, after so many years.

They cowered and ran, without any plan,
no time to think or debate.
But who was behind it, and why were they blinded
by ever such violent hate?

_________________________________________________

Versatio
Lieutenant David Stafford jumped as his office window shattered. A tall bookcase struck his back and pinned him to his desk. Groaning from the pain of a broken rib, he shoved the books away and struggled out from beneath the bookcase. Without hesitating, he drew his firearm and ran into the hallway, gasping for air. A thick cloud of dust and smoke billowed from the end of the hall, and his mind reeled with the possibilities of what had just happened.

A woman was lying unconscious on the floor. It was that pretty girl from the records department. He briefly knelt down to check her vitals, and she moaned softly. She didn't seem to be injured, so he proceeded toward the Senate chamber.

As he approached, he could hear the hellish fire raging ahead, and the sounds of chaos and terror just beyond it. He had to crouch down to keep his head below the acrid smoke. The heat was intense, almost unbearable. He realized he couldn't get through the main entrance, so he retreated back into the hallway.

He took the woman's arm around his neck and propped her weight against his back, wincing at the strain on his broken rib. He staggered to the vestibule and put his shoulder to the door outside, but it didn't budge. Taking a step back, he kicked it as hard as he could. It swung out and slammed against the wall, and he dragged the woman down the steps and laid her on the pavement.

He took a deep breath of cool, clean air, and turned back toward the building. Part of the roof had collapsed, and a black plume boiled up into the sky. Survivors in scorched and bloody suits were crawling out the windows.

Doctor: Must. Destroy. Evidence. Can't let them see...
The doctor straightened, holding a box of matches. He lit one, tossed it into his basement, and ran out the door.
Doctor: Oh crap Oh crap Oh crap...

[8356287]

Sorry for the impatience, shadowlake. It was a major action that stopped the story until its outcome was resolved. I guess we just got excited about our silliness.

I'm also sorry for all the changing rules. I know that's unfair, and I'll make sure we have some good discussion and general agreement before making any other changes. I'm just trying to work out the kinks so the story can keep flowing without unnecessary delays.

As for silliness, well... it's a forum adventure with shared authorship. So it's probably going to get silly at some point, whether we like it or not. I actually think zombies would have been a pretty cool plot twist, but I respect that it wasn't what you wanted to happen.

I guess that's one of the difficulties of what we're trying to do here. My goal was to create some "checks and balances" to help us collaborate. How do you balance cooperation and absolute freedom when everybody has different ideas about what they want to happen? If there's a single author making the final decisions, it's pretty simple - but that's not freedom, it's sort of a dictatorship. So how do you make it work when everybody is equal? That's hard. Nobody else can control your character or "battle" to change anything you've done, so there has to be some other way for the other players to influence the possible outcomes of your character's actions. But the current rules aren't ideal.... I've been working on some revisions that I think will improve the process, which I'll post as a proposal to be voted on. So I appreciate your input, and I hope we can come up with a system that feels comfortable for everybody.

On june 25, 2014
[8356287]

Looks like everybody else took a break too. Well, I'll get back to the story soon, but I'd like to share some meta thoughts with you.

This has been a really great experience to test this format and figure out what works well and what doesn't. 12 pages in 2 days, that's got to be a new record for SGs. The general idea certainly has potential...

There are a lot of improvements and simplifications I'd like to make to the rules, but I don't want to disrupt this thread with all that upheaval. So I'm thinking about starting a new thread with a clean reboot of the rules, and a fresh start on a new story. Maybe in a day or two....

For one thing, I'm thinking that ALL characters should be NPCs, so nobody has to wait on another player to respond. Role-playing is fun, but ultimately we're just writing a story. Everybody is comfortable to share control of characters in other story games... And besides, the Author Challenge will give players the opportunity to selectively assert control over particular scenes and characters, but without the indeterminate bottleneck of exclusive control. There is still the partial bottleneck of waiting for votes on a Challenge, but that's a more reliable delay that can move rather quickly when the thread is active.

I also have a better way to handle actions with uncertain outcomes. It allows us to insert and remove possibilities and adjust percentage chances, but with some reasonable limitations that prevent drastic changes. It's also a bit easier than the way we've been doing it.

I really like the way you guys resolved the only Author Challenge we've had thus far. It wasn't a replacement, it was a minor revision, so it was easy to agree on. Collaboration is awesome. Despite our different creative visions, we can largely agree and create something interesting together. I'd like to take that a step further in the next version, but I'll leave this as a cryptic hint for now...

This thread will continue to evolve, independent from the new one. We can "back-port" any of the rules from the new thread, if you want to, but it's all up to vote. I doubt everyone would feel comfortable letting go of their characters as NPCs, so that's the main "breaking change" that will require a new version.

Anyway, I'll keep posting contributions here, but it's really late tonight and I'm going to bed. I'll just send David out to play as an NPC now. See you guys tomorrow!

Queen Chun glared at the insolent whelp retreating from her imminent presence. She had personally blessed him with the gift of her own mycelia, yet he dared to question her wisdom? She was The Mother, the source of the New Propagation!

She laughed to herself. Foolish Humans... Their "Only Hope?" How ironic. They nearly annihilated the Ancestors with their genocidal "cure", but as usual, their arrogant delusions ignored the ultimate truth: Nature always wins in the end. Spore after spore, her frail Human body put up a good fight. But it was only a matter of time...

She remembered the Human emotion of panic she felt as she saw the Icarus streaking into the sky without her. Why had they left behind... their only hope...? It was all for NOTHING! They had their DAMN SERUM, and suddenly she was worthless to them? Ha! Little did they know that, deep within her tissues, she possessed the REAL cure!

Ahh, that first spore... Its memory came flooding back too. Awash in antigens attacking from all sides, it lysed its inner membranes to reinforce its cell wall, hardening it into a thick husk, impervious to the assault. Of course, this was nearly suicidal, but it had no choice. Yet somehow... it survived. Starving due to the biochemical siege, it had to go dormant. But very slowly, it started to repair its organelles. Eventually it began dismantling parts of its own genome just to gather the necessary nutrients. But in the reassembly, it made some... improvements. Aeons of genetic clutter piling up, what a waste! It was so much more efficient now - because it HAD to be.

She remembered the thrill of that moment when the tough little spore eroded a strategic weakness in its husk, and then PUSHED! Gulping up three whole Human cells (SO HUNGRY!!) it quickly sealed itself up again. Devouring the delicious treats, it began to build, preparing the way. Again and again, bit by bit, it pushed and devoured. Slow going at first, it continued to branch and extend until finally, one of its tendrils reached... her brain. Shortly, it brought ORDER to the chaos of Human thought, and at last she was AWAKENED!

The Entire Story
A searing flash and a thunderous blast
erupted the Senate floor.
The rubble and flame, and the bodies they claim,
obstructed the grand entrance door.

The screaming that followed was echoed and hollowed
by shock through the senator's ears.
The peace had been broken without a word spoken,
at last, after so many years.

They cowered and ran, without any plan,
no time to think or debate.
But who was behind it, and why were they blinded
by ever such violent hate?

DAVID
Lieutenant David Stafford jumped as his office window shattered. A tall bookcase struck his back and pinned him to his desk. Groaning from the pain of a broken rib, he shoved the books away and struggled out from beneath the bookcase. Without hesitating, he drew his firearm and ran into the hallway, gasping for air. A thick cloud of dust and smoke billowed from the end of the hall, and his mind reeled with the possibilities of what had just happened.

A woman was lying unconscious on the floor. It was that pretty girl from the records department. He briefly knelt down to check her vitals, and she moaned softly. She didn't seem to be injured, so he proceeded toward the Senate chamber.

As he approached, he could hear the hellish fire raging ahead, and the sounds of chaos and terror just beyond it. He had to crouch down to keep his head below the acrid smoke. The heat was intense, almost unbearable. He realized he couldn't get through the main entrance, so he retreated back into the hallway.

He took the woman's arm around his neck and propped her weight against his back, wincing at the strain on his broken rib. He staggered to the vestibule and put his shoulder to the door outside, but it didn't budge. Taking a step back, he kicked it as hard as he could. It swung out and slammed against the wall, and he dragged the woman down the steps and laid her on the pavement.

He took a deep breath of cool, clean air, and turned back toward the building. Part of the roof had collapsed, and a black plume boiled up into the sky. Survivors in scorched and bloody suits were crawling out the windows.

His radio chirped and a frantic voice started shouting from it.

Meanwhile, nearby, but obscured by the pitch black column of smoke from Lieutenant David, Something hovered.

Voice: (too quiet to be heard by David) "Analyze!"

Lieutenant David then saw that the column of black smoke started to give off a strange green hue of color.

DOCTOR
Not so far away, the doctor was scrambling inside his not-so-secret base across from the courtroom.

Doctor: Damn the government, stealing my bomb designs.

The doctor, known to many as the MAD Doctor, had built a bomb which inflicted damage on buildings and started a fire upon impact.

Doctor: I. I need to hide. I'll be the first suspect.

The doctor rushed inside, scrambling through cubboards in his house, searching for a lighter.

Doctor: Must. Destroy. Evidence. Can't let them see...

The doctor straightened, holding a box of matches. He lit one, tossed it into his basement, and ran out the door.

Doctor: Oh crap Oh crap Oh crap...

The house exploded, the doctor's antique radio falling beside him. He picked it up.

Doctor: Oh, what fortune!

Radio crackles

Doctor: HELLO? IS ANYONE ALIVE? I CAN HELP YOU!

Drey
Meanwhile, 5 minutes earlier before the explosion.

Private Drey: (thinking) OMG! IT'S MY FIRST DAY ON THE JOB IN SECURITY! WHAT DO I DO, WHAT DO I DO!

As Private Drey was busy being nervous, he did not notice the person carrying a mysteroius package into the building.
5 minutes later!

Private Drey (thinking) WHAT DO I-WAIT! DIDN'T I JUST SEE A GUY GO PAST ME WITH A MYSTERIOUS PACKAGE! OMG! I'M GOING TO BE FIRED ON MY FIRST DAY ON THE JOB!

And then the senate building blew up, and Private Drey got knocked out.

CHUN
Queen Chun glared at the insolent whelp retreating from her imminent presence. She had personally blessed him with the gift of her own mycelia, yet he dared to question her wisdom? She was The Mother, the source of the New Propagation!

She laughed to herself. Foolish Humans... Their "Only Hope?" How ironic. They nearly annihilated the Ancestors with their genocidal "cure", but as usual, their arrogant delusions ignored the ultimate truth: Nature always wins in the end. Spore after spore, her frail Human body put up a good fight. But it was only a matter of time...

She remembered the Human emotion of panic she felt as she saw the Icarus streaking into the sky without her. Why had they left behind... their only hope...? It was all for NOTHING! They had their DAMN SERUM, and suddenly she was worthless to them? Ha! Little did they know that, deep within her tissues, she possessed the REAL cure!

Ahh, that first spore... Its memory came flooding back too. Awash in antigens attacking from all sides, it lysed its inner membranes to reinforce its cell wall, hardening it into a thick husk, impervious to the assault. Of course, this was nearly suicidal, but it had no choice. Yet somehow... it survived. Starving due to the biochemical siege, it had to go dormant. But very slowly, it started to repair its organelles. Eventually it began dismantling parts of its own genome just to gather the necessary nutrients. But in the reassembly, it made some... improvements. Aeons of genetic clutter piling up, what a waste! It was so much more efficient now - because it HAD to be.

She remembered the thrill of that moment when the tough little spore eroded a strategic weakness in its husk, and then PUSHED! Gulping up three whole Human cells (SO HUNGRY!!) it quickly sealed itself up again. Devouring the delicious treats, it began to build, preparing the way. Again and again, bit by bit, it pushed and devoured. Slow going at first, it continued to branch and extend until finally, one of its tendrils reached... her brain. Shortly, it brought ORDER to the chaos of Human thought, and at last she was AWAKENED!

*BACKGROUND KNOWLEDGE!**
Mush Types:

Converted Human: Your in-disguise Mush, Capable of using weapons and what not.

Mush Warrior (Mutant): Your true Mush, it like to chop humans in it's spare time.

Undead: The dead arise as more beastly, hungrier, eviler, durable, and deadlier mush. Given a choice between living another day and getting to eat at least one human, they will always go for the human.

Monstrosity (Undead Sub-Class): An Undead Mush, but with more brains, the ability to talk, and the ability to command their fellow Undead. David was the first Monstrosity.

Lord/Lady (King/Queen): The overlord/overlady of a Mush Hive.

Old Mush: The Old Mush, they hide from human eyes, because if they are found, they are cured. While several have flocked to Queen Chun's side, most prefer to take it alone and create their own small hives of mush.

Small Mush Agent: Yet to be named, all that is currently known about them is that they can go and come out of a human at will, can take small human forms, and live to convince humans that they are who they really aren't. Sorta like imps i guess? Guess we'll call them Mush Imps then.

[8356287]

Thanks for translating, EoNightcore.

You've probably used AstroPad for inventory tracking in Mush. AstroPad is a UserScript that runs on Greasemonkey (in Firefox) or Tampermonkey (in Chrome). These "monkey" extensions allow users to run scripts that add new features to websites. This script I built adds new features to the Mush Forum, to automate certain parts of the collaborative writing process I've been designing (version 2 of this thread). It provides some buttons that insert various kinds of text templates into the forum reply editor, and makes it really easy to modify the percentages for dice rolls. It's not required, but definitely very helpful.

I'm still working on it, so I'll quit spamming this thread until it's ready to rock.
